instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bios keeps dying
threads.message:
Had corrosion on resistors near bios. Replaced all. 
MacBook works fine but after sleeping overnight it won’t turn on. Replaced SMC, no change. I was removing jtag it turned on then didn’t when cooled. This led me to discovering if I heat the BIOS chip it turns on. Replaced and all is good until the next morning - same issue. 
what could be killing the BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bios keeps dying
threads.message:
Did you replace <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, or reflash it only?
Check ALL SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces; few of them are far away (of BIOS), under PCH area.
Also heat PCH/CPU with good flux; to burn eventually accumulated crap.
